3. We will expect to find the version number, RSA modulus n, RSA public exponent e, RSA private exponent d, prime factor p of n, prime factor q of n, d mod (p-1), d mod (q-1), CRT coefficient q^(-1) mod p . All of these numbers are needed to decypher the encrypted message we receive (this way if someone else tries to read it, they can't).  

4. We opened the link Lapo Luchini's ASN.1 decoder, copied our RSA private key file contents, pasted them into the website, and pressed the decode button. 

5. What is the meaning/name of the integer? This should correspond to one of the items in your answer to the previous question, articulated as an ASN.1 name from the specification in RFC 8017.
What is the value of the integer? Write the integer in either decimal or hexadecimal, whichever is more convenient. If hexadecimal, prepend the integer with "0x".

The integer 0 tells us the version the RSA used (0x020100). The integer that you get when you multiple p and q (two large prime numbers randomly chosen) is called the modulus integer:  . The value of the public exponent is 0x0203010001, this is the hex value of the RSA public exponent. It is what others can see and use to send information to us, as it is part of the public key. The hexadecimal value  is the private exponent of this RSA private key, commonly known as d. It is what we use to see the messages that are sent to us. The hexadecimal value  is the prime factor p of n, which is used to calculate the modulus. The hexadeicmal value  is the prime factor q of n, which is used to calculate the modulus. Exponent 1, represented by the hexadecimal value , is d mod (p-1), the secret value that is used to decrypt cypertext created using the corresponding public key. Exponent 2, represented by the hexadecimal value , is d mod (q-1), the secret value that is used to decrypt cypertext created using the corresponding public key. The coefficient integer is the CRT coefficient q^(-1) mod p, the hexadecimal value is .

Sanity Check
9. The public key's modulus n and the private key's modulus n are the same! Additionally, the RSA public exponent e value is the same in both the private and public key. We almost went insane when trying to calculate the modulus decimal value (n) with the private exponent q and the public exponent p. When we tried to compare p*q with n, we should have gotten the same value however we were unable to do so for unknown reasons. On the other hand, when we got the decimal amount of the modulus for both the private and public key, the value was the same, thus leaving us confused.
